issues.description: The problem statement inconsistently uses two different method names for the same behavior: the UML and several tasks require an abstract method messageOnFeed():String (see UML/task declarations), but other places (Part 2 and Part 3) refer to getFeedingSound() (e.g. "getFeedingSound() should return ..." and "feedAllAnimals() calls getFeedingSound() ..."). This naming inconsistency can confuse students about which method to implement and call, and may lead to compilation/test failures if they implement one name while the tests/template expect the other. The solution and intended design use messageOnFeed(), so the problem text should consistently use that name.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the method name across the problem statement, template, and tests. Prefer the name used in the UML and solution: messageOnFeed():String. Replace all occurrences of getFeedingSound() in the problem text (and any hints) with messageOnFeed(). Optionally, add a clarifying note that feedAllAnimals() should call Animal.messageOnFeed() and print its returned String.

issues.description: The problem statement inconsistently refers to the animal feeding-sound method with two different identifiers: messageOnFeed() (used in the UML and task 1) and getFeedingSound() (used in Part 2 examples). The template/solution codebase consistently uses messageOnFeed(). This mismatch can confuse students about which method they must implement and call when producing the feeding sound.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the feeding-sound method name consistent across all artifacts. Replace the occurrences of getFeedingSound() in the problem statement with messageOnFeed(), so the textual description, UML, template hints, and solution all refer to the same identifier (messageOnFeed()). Update example lines in Part 2 to state: messageOnFeed() should return "Arf Arf!" / "Oink!" / "Maah!" respectively.
